pr_title: xds: add onResourceDoesNotExist API for resource watchers

timeline.message: Refactor watcher interface definition to add an onResourceDoesNotExist api.
Invoke onResourceDoesNotExist when receiving xDS responses for resource not found.
Change xDS resolver to use onResourceDoesNotExist() for resource not found.
Implement onResourceDoesNotExist in CDS lb policy.
Implement onResourceDoesNotExist in EDS lb policy.
Change Listener watcher to use onResourceDoesNotExist api.

timeline.bodyText: Based on the code elsewhere, it looks like you don't wait for a DiscoveryResponse before calling this but you may call it if you found resourceName in the absent*Resources set. Is that semantic correct and agreeable to everyone?
timeline.author: sanjaypujare

replies.bodyText: absent*Resources is the cache for resources that known to be absent. For example, if some watcher is already watching resource A (sent A in request), but A does not exist. We need to memorize this information. When another watcher is added to also watch A, we know immediately it doesn't exist. If we do not memorize that information, the second watcher will never get notified.
replies.author: voidzcy

timeline.bodyText: The actual resource name used in the request in this case was null/empty string. But you are reporting it as ":" + listenerPort. I don't have a better suggestion other than to put a comment mentioning that.
timeline.author: sanjaypujare

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, I noticed that. Maybe the doc on onResourceDoesNotExist() is somewhat imprecise. The argument is the resource name that we are looking for but does not exist. I am going to update that.
For Listener watcher, this is kind of ambiguous as it sits on the border of the design (i.e., the way we watch Listener is to request all and select the one we are seeking for). But at least, using ":" + listenerPort turns out to be better than using null/empty string.
Actually ConfigWatcher also has somewhat similar issue, since resource-not-found may be caused by the intermediate RDS lookup, which uses a different resource name (other than what was used for registering the watcher) for the discovery request. In that case, the onResourceDoesNotExist() callback is invoked (and IMO it should be) with the actual requested RDS resource name.
replies.author: voidzcy
